item.title: The white hot new arts review
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: The White Review is a radical new not-for-profit arts quarterly launching in print and online in January 2011. Edited by Jacques Testard and Ben Eastham, the magazine aims to promote the best of a new generation of artists and writers. The first issue will feature interviews with Paula Rego and Tom McCarthy, and new artwork by Viktor Timofeev and Lawrence Lek as well as new fiction, poetry, essays, and reportage. The name – the White Review – is a reference to La Revue Blanche, a Parisian political, literary and artistic magazine which ran from 1889 to 1903. Politically, La Revue Blanche fought against the injustices of its time.  Established on a non-profit economic model, The White Review seeks to follow in the footsteps of La Revue Blanche by providing a platform for a new generation of writers, thinkers, and artists to break through. We have an exclusive Apollinaire trusteeship of The White Review to be won. Worth a £100 donation, Apollinaire trusteeship  includes a subscription to the review and participation in their collaborative editing project.  To enter email a.castleton@arts.ac.uk with your name, email address, postal address and phone number, with "Arts Hotlist The White Review competition" in the subject line by 31 January. Read more about The White Review at www.thewhitereview.org or http://www.wefund.co.uk/project/white-review. To find out more email Jacques at thewhitereview@gmail.com.

item.title: Arts London in the news 1
item.dc:creator: aasmith
item.content:encoded: Future fashion, disposable dilemmas and ripping into arts cuts - a taste of University of the Arts London in the news this week 20 predictions for the next 25 years - The Observer New technologies will give us intelligent clothing that fits better and allows consumers to make more informed ethical choices, says Dilys Williams of London College of Fashion, in the Observer’s start-of-the-year forecast of what the next 25 years may hold. “This is partly driven by customer demand and the desire to know where clothing comes from,” she says. “So we'll see tags on garments that tell you where every part of it was made, and some of this, I suspect, will be legislation-driven, too, for similar reasons, particularly as resources become scarcer and it becomes increasingly important to recognise water and carbon footprints.” Disposable dilemma – The Financial Times The rise of disposable fashion could pose a threat to future costume archives and leave holes in fashion history, experts warn in the Financial Times. However Louise Wilson of Central Saint Martins comments that this ‘fast fashion’ could redefine what is collectable. “If everyone thinks ‘Sod it, I paid hardly anything for it and will chuck it out after a few wears’, that means in the future, few products will survive that cull, and could become collectable,” she says. Arts cuts are like ripping up the Magna Carter – The Guardian Artist Bob and Robert Smith (also known as Patrick Brill) criticises plans to cut funding for the arts and for arts education, writing in the Guardian that art schools “are places of social interchange where the wealthy intermingle with the deserving and Britain’s culture is hot-housed.” He adds: “My father was one of the people who benefited from these changes. A working-class lad, his life was transformed because he could draw and paint. In the 1960s and 70s he ran the Chelsea School of Art.” Lyrical gifts – The Financial Times Recent graduate of Wimbledon College of Art Nathan Cash Davidson is “the most original and surprising painter to emerge from a British art school in the past half-decade”, according to critic Jackie Wullschlager writing in the Financial Times. “A critic’s job is to find and draw attention to the best culture of our times, and especially to enlighten and entertain readers with fresh, significant voices,” she adds. “Cash Davidson is one such figure. Nothing makes you understand art better than living with it, and seeing his paintings daily made me appreciate not only his work but a whole mood in young 21st-century painting where opulent materiality and eclectic imagination coexist with a resolutely contemporary sensibility.” **A weekly overview of some of the stories from University of the Arts London making the news is published online every Friday. item.title: Letter to all staff from the Rector
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
Dear Colleagues
Happy New Year and welcome back to the Spring term.
Many of you attended my recent all staff meetings at which I updated you on the tough challenges being faced by everyone in the higher education sector as undergraduate student fees increase very substantially in 2012 but cuts to our direct Government funding start as early as April this year.
Many of you will have seen the Government’s announcement just prior to Christmas that the overall HE teaching funding grant is to be reduced next year by more than 8% when adjusted for inflation and that additional cuts are expected to other HE funding streams. We will not know exactly how this will affect us until we receive our individual allocation from HEFCE in a few months time but recent experience indicates that our share of the cut is likely to be more than the average for the sector because we do not teach or conduct research in prioritised Science and Technology subjects.
As I explained at our all-staff meetings, we have to make significant savings in our recurrent costs to prepare for the new financial environment and to ensure that we continue to be a sustainable, world-class university attractive to future students. To do so we must focus as much as possible of our resource base on student-facing activity and ensure that we maximise the efficiency of all our support services. We must also retain a balance sheet that enables us to invest in new programmes and courses as well as an excellent teaching, learning, research and working environment for all our staff and students.
This is a tremendous challenge for us – as it is for all universities - and it is a challenge to which we must respond quickly so that we commence the 2011-12 academic year with a cost base which reflects our reduced funding income.
We have calculated that, in order to address the challenge for 2011-12, we must reduce our recurrent costs by at least £8m before the end of this financial year and we have commenced consultation with our recognised trade unions about the proposed changes to the University’s Central Services today. Affected staff will be involved in initial discussions with their managers this week. Later this month we will also be considering plans for further savings and (where appropriate) additional income generation within the Colleges.
I recognise that such major change is very unsettling. This is deeply regrettable but I believe that, by going through this significant pain now, we could avoid the need for future major cross-University efficiency programmes, although in the current climate this cannot of course be guaranteed.
Much work has gone into the preparations for these savings. Many managers have been withholding vacancies and employing temporary staff. We have also managed to redeploy 19 staff in the last 12 months to avoid external recruitment. We remain committed to using redeployment where it is sensible to do so, and to supporting staff who do, unfortunately, face the prospect of their post being no longer required.
I will continue to update all staff regularly on the proposed changes.
Yours
Nigel Carrington Rector

item.title: Interview: Sroop Sunar
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
D&AD New Blood Award winner Sroop Sunar brings a punchy new show to the Arts Gallery this January, pitching the great British boozer as an unlikely design icon. Just in time for  new year's detox resolutions to falter, Sroop invites you to explore a visual history of inebriated England through a show which reimagines the traditional pub sign.

Born in Birmingham, Sroop moved to New Delhi in her teens where her love for Indian street culture and printed ephemera began. From textile to matchbox labels, hair oil to medicine packaging, it was the haphazard printing quality, striking colour palettes, quirky use of typography and visual wit found on every day Indian consumer goods that influenced her work. The unusual stylization of Sroop's illustration offers a unique cultural aesthetic, presenting India's quirky post-colonial design culture to a Western audience.Graduating from Central Saint Martins in 2009, her final year dissertation won her a D&AD Best New Blood award. Her clients include Penguin Books, Profile Books, Random House, BP, It's Nice That, Habitat, Civil Justice Association of California and Howies. Following exhibitions in London and Berlin, first solo show, The Golden Glassy, opens at the Arts Gallery on 20 January.

What are you working on at the moment? My first solo show opens in a week on Wednesday so I am manically trying to finish everything off in preparation for it!!! It's not that I'm not prepared, that would be utterly disastrous, I just tend to leave dozens of minor things to the final moments (headless chicken syndrome?). I guess it makes things more exciting, thrilling, terrifying... its a good rush and my best work always comes from high pressure environments and feeling a sense of urgency, so I must intentionally create these situations even though I don't plan for it. Come to think about it, it's actually really annoying! I'm also working on my first commission of the year so all in all, 2011 has started with a bang.

What are your top tips for discovering new talent? I find Twitter to be an excellent place to find out about stuff like this. I follow all of my favourite blogs, illustrators, agencies, publications etc - they're all really active online and its a great place to discover new talent. I'm also starting work at D&AD on the Student Awards a bit later this year. I'm really excited about it, I can't wait to see all of the work, hear what the judges say, and see what gets awarded what. Hopefully I'll be seeing some amazing things, then I can tell you all about the ones to watch!

Who is your one to watch? I went to see Alex Ball's show at the Arts Gallery last November and I was blown away by his work. His paintings are just incredible.

Who or what first inspired you to follow your chosen career? I wouldn't say there was one single person who inspired me to become an illustrator. I never set out to become one. It could easily have gone in the opposite direction had my parents said to me "there's no way you're going to art school". So their encouragement and support has allowed me to do what I'm doing right now. I've always been "the arty one" for as far back as I can remember- I can't explain it. I guess "creation" - or something along those lines - was the philosophy I was meant to live by. Or maybe I just watched too much Art Attack as a child...

What are you most passionate about? Lots of things - I'm mad on vintage illustration, I love music, good food, my amazing family,  Spanish language, a really great advert/piece of communication, making things, my gorgeous Karen Millen winter coat, amazing music videos, running... just anything beautiful and creative, thought provoking and inspiring... it's hard to pinpoint. I think in the long run, my passions are to reach the goals I set myself. And these, I am still figuring out! Which piece of art/design/performance/communication/fashion do you wish you had created? 1950s and 60s Eastern European matchbox labels amaze me. This area of the world was embracing modern design whilst everywhere else, including Britain, still preferred the Victorian aesthetic. I really love these illustration styles- the labels are so clear and informative. It suits the subject matter too, commonly dealing with public service type announcements such as fire safety, hygiene, money saving, alcohol abuse and road safety subjects. The colour composition, symmetry and message style is so direct. I wish I made them!

Where is your favourite London haunt? FABRIC!

What is your guilty pleasure? King size twix and Neighbours.

Name a favourite book, song or film Kaleidoscope - Logistics. Definitely one of my all time favourites.

What is your signature dish? My macaroni and cheese is known to be pretty spectacular. It goes above and beyond what you would expect from an otherwise ordinary dish. It's comfort food at it's finest, and it is positively divine! I also make excellent potato wedges.

What’s next for you? I have absolutely no idea. My eyes and ears are open, I'm ready to go wherever the wind takes me. I have a good feeling about my first solo show and I hope it will open some new doors.

item.title: URETHRA POSTCARD ART of Gilbert and George
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: Gilbert & George begin the new year maintaining the status quo, keeping up their tradition of eye-brow raising art shows. This time White Cube plays host to the largest ever exhibition from their POSTCARD ART series, which takes picture postcards, telephone box cards and flyers as their  medium. Michael Bracewell, in the exhibition catalogue, explains how "Gilbert & George describe, in THE URETHRA POSTCARD PICTURES, both a modern urban world and a sexual society that is covert or marginalised within that world. In this group of pictures, prostitution and sexually transmitted disease (for example) are treated with precisely the same sense of scale, aesthetic and compositional language as nationhood and civic identity... In their sheer visual intensity, the extremism of their language, and above all the forceful unity of their composition, THE URETHRA POSTCARD PICTURES both extend the POSTCARD ART of Gilbert & George as a specific form, and comprise one of the most powerful, mesmeric, and intensely conceived and created groups of art works that the artists have ever made." Jonathan Jones in The Guardian comments "In these works, Gilbert and George seem to be channelling the city, letting it flow through them. This paper trail – of London sights and its citizen's secret affairs – adds up to a monstrous portrait of the city, in all its bombast and sleaze... Here, the city seems to press more heavily than ever at their sluice gates, which open in sudden ecstasy, to spray out these unvalued treasures." Fisun Guner at The Arts Desk concludes "the works themselves, seeped in their seedy nostalgia, throb with a sense of aching loneliness and longing. Rather Larkinesque, one might argue." John-Paul Pryor interviewed the art duo for Dazed Digital; they reveal "Gilbert: We think the artists and the writers and the editors and so on do have a duty [to challenge the viewer and challenge society]. Every person has a gaping hole inside of them that can only be filled by music or poetry or philosophy, or exhibitions or something. George: Art is quite limited but it is part of change and finding out a way to live – liberating ourselves from all these conventions that we learned. Gilbert: We all have 2000 years of chains that we can only get rid of a little bit at a time with reading this book or that book, or having a conversation. But nobody is free of these chains – we can’t be. " Gilbert & George met as students of the St Martin's sculpture course.

item.title: Future Perfect
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
Industrial activity and waste management in East London had contaminated the soils of the future Olympic Park for decades. London 2012 has long been cleaning the site, starting at the time of the Olympic bid. Victoria Lee, a CSM MA Creative Practice for Narrative Environments student, has developed an innovative alternative solution to wash-cleaning that might be used in the future to the benefit of community life in the Olympic Park after the Games.

She presents a eco-sensitive and cost-effective solution for remediation of contaminated soils and site transformation that builds on agricultural and social sciences. Victoria uses bioremediation – plants and micro-organisms that absorb poisons – to clean the contaminated soils in and around the Olympic Park. This method is less costly and a more natural way of remediating than soil-washing. Victoria has made this time element an asset in her project, enabling local communities to impact on the remediation and transformation of the site, including newcomers to the Olympic Legacy Park.A longer-term solution, the overall cleaning of the site using this gentle cleansing method would require 10 years. Through this narrative, she reminds us that life takes time to develop and settle. More than an architectural transformation of the Olympic site, she proposes a metamorphosis of it into a nice place to live in. Read more

The Observer began the year by making 20 predictions for the next 25 years, suggesting what the next quarter century may hold across all areas of modern life. Dilys Williams, director for sustainable fashion at LCF, predicts that  "in the coming decades, I think there'll be much more emphasis on other manifestations of fashion and different ways of communicating with each other, different ways of creating a sense of belonging and of making us feel great about ourselves. Technology is already being used to create clothing that fits better and is smarter; it is able to transmit a degree of information back to you. This is partly driven by customer demand and the desire to know where clothing comes from. So we’ll see tags on garments that tell you where every part of it was made, and some of this, I suspect, will be legislation-driven, too, for similar reasons, particularly as resources become scarcer and it becomes increasingly important to recognise water and carbon footprints.” Read more Recent LCF student Ada Zanditon has been making headlines with her biomimicry fashion designs – "sustainable design innovation inspired by the natural world". She told the Guardian "It's using concepts that haven't been seen in fashion before...  I  knew I wanted to do something different. Fashion is just a form of communication. Unfortunately now there is lots of repetition in the way fashion communicates." Ada's designs deploy recycled denim yarn, fair-trade organic cotton or reclaimed polyester.  "I hope the lifespan of my clothes is 30 to 40 years. Eventually they will be finished, and at that point I want them to be compostable, not sitting in perpetuity in landfill" she explains. Read more

item.title: Modern British Sculpture
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: The Royal Academy of Arts presents a monumental show examining British sculpture of the twentieth century, the first of its kind in 30 years. This ground-breaking show presents a unique view of the development of British sculpture, "exploring the terms British and sculpture by bringing the two together, each making its own visual argument". Challenging the viewer to make new connections and break the mould of old conceptions, the exhibition will present key figures from the history of modern British art who are intrinsically linked to the development of the contemporary British art school scene, including CSM alumni Anthony Caro, Richard Long, former Chelsea Head of Sculpture Henry Moore,  and Chelsea alumnus Julian Opie. We have five pairs of tickets to give away. For a chance to win email a.castleton@arts.ac.uk with your name, phone number and postal address, using the subject line "Arts Hotlist RA Competition" by 15 February. item.title: Jewel in the crown
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
The first blockbuster film of 2011 is without doubt The King's Speech, but will it be the crown jewel in this year's Oscars?  The Brit flick sees Colin Firth take on the role of Prince Albert, Duke of York, portraying the future King George VI in his bid to overcome his stutter. The film reveals Albert's relationship with his unconventional speech therapist, Lionel Logue, whose unusual methods help the monarch as he prepares to for his first speech on the radio. Peter Bradshaw in The Guardian reports "The King's Speech proves there's fizzing life in old-school British period dramas – it's acted and directed with such sweep, verve, [and] darting lightness. George VI's talking cure is gripping." Anthony Quinn in The Independent pronounces it "well put together and beautifully played by its leads". Sukhdev Sandhu in The Telegraph describes "a thoroughly modern tale, the true-life story of a king’s efforts to overcome his stammer in order to face his public, constructed like a contemporary makeover narrative. " The Drama Centre trained actor won Best Actor at this Sunday's Golden Globes, has been nominated for Best Actor at the BAFTAs and for the coveted Best Actor Oscar . The King's Speech won the 2010 Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award in September. This week Colin has been further cementing his place in the Hollywood firmament, receiving a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Read the full report in The Independent.

Colin Firth came to Drama Centre London at Central Saint Martins in 2009 to speak to a packed hall of students about acting and his career.  He answered many questions with great honesty and warmth and has recently strengthened his ties to the college by becoming Honorary President of The Friends of Drama Centre. http://courses.csm.arts.ac.uk/drama/friends.asp

“It is very exciting to see one of our alumni build an impressive body of work that is recognised by the most prestigious awards,” says Principal of the Drama Centre, Professor Vladimir Mirodan, “Colin was always a very dedicated and gifted student and everyone here will be rooting for him on the night.”

To receive a daily email round-up of all coverage, subscribe to the Daily Press Bulletin by sending your email address to press.office@arts.ac.uk ** Ada Zanditon's innovation: sustainable biomimicry clothes - The Observer The diversity of life on earth is the inspiration of London College of Fashion graduate Ada Zanditon, whose sustainable designs are examined in the Observer. Using recycled, reclaimed and organic materials, she aims to make fashion with a long life: "I hope the lifespan of my clothes is 30 to 40 years. Eventually they will be finished, and at that point I want them to be compostable, not sitting in perpetuity in landfill." Peter Mandelson revealed himself to be "a big design buff", and Grayson Perry arrived in an outfit created by one of his Central Saint Martins students. "I came to study the difference between the design and art world," he said. "So far I find the design world more clean-cut than the arts. Mimsy is the right word." Amongst the up and coming designers, Elle highlights Central Saint Martins graduates Anja Mlaka and Kirsty Ward as names to remember. item.title: A Public Nuisance
item.dc:creator: matt
item.content:encoded:
Since graduating from Camberwell BA Graphic Design in 2008 James Naimi-Akbar or ‘Aki’ as you may know him has been working as the in house designer for Diesel, freelance for other brands such as The Dune Group (Dune, Bertie and Pied de Terre) and of course doing the obligatory jobs for friends and family.

However, Aki has now started out on a new venture alongside business partner Rupert Leigh, whom he met whilst at Diesel and in November 2010 they announced the launch of ‘A Public Nuisance’, ‘essential apparel with a mischievous spirit’, or APN as it will be known.

APN takes it’s name from a passage describing photographer Craig R Stecyk III’s (Zephyr store co founder) visual lexicon on graffiti skateboard design when it was still considered a low rent ‘public nuisance’. There are many essential influences that have helped create APN, from ‘MAD’ magazine, B-movies, the cub-scouts and being noticed when you want to be noticed.

There are 3 components that make up the brand:

  • APN – Essential Apparel.
  • SWL ‘StuffWeLike’ – Interaction / Community / Association.
  • 27 – Giving others opportunities.

Check them out at – www.apublicnuisance.com

Or email – aki@apublicnuisance.com

item.title: Field of dreams
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
"This is a very personal book, one that will inspire art lovers, gardeners and anyone with a love of the natural world", say House and Garden of Plants and Places, CSM trained designer Angie Lewin's new book. Lewin has one of the most distinctive styles among contemporary British nature artists. The Norfolk based designer explains "I try to find how best to depict a plant’s structure and character, not with botanical accuracy but by capturing its distinctive characteristics."

Plants and Places presents more than 80 of Lewin’s beautifully crafted linocuts and wood engravings, grouping them according to habitat, such as coast, woodland and hedgerow, and meadow and garden. Elle Decoration describe the new work as "a delight for gardeners and nature lovers". We have five signed copies of Plants and Places to give away. item.title: Speedo team up with LCF
item.dc:creator: ssaggar
item.content:encoded:
The Speedo LZR RACER was the most technologically advanced performance swimsuit ever produced. However, due to recent rule changes, a large number of the suits are now obsolete. Speedo approached the BA (Hons) Fashion Sportswear and BA (Hons) Fashion Contour courses to develop innovative designs that re-used, re-designed and re-manufactured the LZR Racers into new products.

At the core of the brief was considering the environmental impact and suitability for future reuse, re-manufacture or recycling as part of a ‘lifecycle strategy.’ Students were set the challenging task of designing fashion forward commercial pieces that had the potential to go into production that also kept sustainability at the heart of the design.

After coming up with sketches, concepts and prototypes Speedo were delighted with the end results and conducted a photoshoot with some of the final designs. Speedo also created a pop up exhibition of the project work at the World Swimming Championships in Dubai which took place in December 2010.

The creations included several examples of drawing on the suit’s heritage in the pool, including a patchwork watershort using the LZR Racer and other Speedo watershorts sourced on auction websites by Man Kit Au Yeung (BA (Hons) Fashion Sportswear) and an ‘Afterlife’ creation featuring a cape inspired by superheroes and aimed at the high-end fashion market by Eva Hiu Wa Lai (BA (Hons) Fashion Contour).

President of Speedo, David Robinson, said: “This project has captured the technology and originality of the Speedo LZR Racer and combined it with unique cutting edge fashion. It is inspiring to see the creative and innovative approach the students have taken to produce their products.”

item.title: Camberwell Alumnus Appointed ICA Director
item.dc:creator: matt
item.content:encoded:
Gregor Muir – Camberwell Painting alumnus (1985-88) has been appointed as the new executive director of the ICA London.

Muir has been the director of one of the world’s leading galleries, Hauser & Wirth since 2004. He has previously served as a curator at the Tate as well as founding the Lux Gallery in 1997.

Muir said “Since my first visit to the ICA as a student in the 1980s, I have become tremendously attached to this unique and inspiring institution,” he said. “As Sir Roland Penrose, co-founder of the ICA, said in 1968, the role of the ICA is ‘stimulating interest in the works of artists and ideas formerly unfamiliar to us.’

“Now more than ever, the ICA is needed to give artists a voice, allowing them to display their work while exploring new ideas in a welcoming environment. I very much look forward to being a part of the ICA’s future.”

Alison Myners (ICA chair) said “He brings to the ICA many years of experience from both public and private sectors at a time when knowledge of both is so important. Gregor will once again place artists at the heart of the ICA, making it a forum for new ideas and discussion, exciting audiences and restoring the ICA as a destination.”

item.title: Power of Ten up for Design Award
item.dc:creator: admin8d4e25
item.content:encoded:
The LCC Summer Shows, Power of Ten, designed and curated by Morag Myerscough have been nominated for a Brit Insurance Design Award.

Shortlisted in the graphics category, Studio Myerscough has said of the project (which encompassed the College’s four summer degree shows):

 “The work so far reflects both LCC’s rich typographic, print and design heritage and the distinctive tactile and expressive qualities of the specialist studio-based education that takes place within it.  The continuation of the project into the triangular ‘piazza’ outside the college, with its shipping container galleries, carnivalesque spaces, seating areas, effects a permeable extension of what goes on inside the college into the outside, and has made a dynamic start to the regeneration of the otherwise brutal and uncompromising urban space around it. The placemaking and wayfinding with its extension outside bridges the college and external Elephant & Castle environments, and gives life to both: a powerful first step to a new image and identity for the College and a sense of pride in community as the Elephant & Castle regenerates.”

The project will be on show in the Design Museum from 16 February to 7 August, with an overall winner announced on 15 March. You can read the glowing reviews of the shows for yourself here on the HoC blog. The shows have also earned themselves a mention in today’s Guardian!

item.title: University of the Arts London and London Studio Centre end merger talks
item.dc:creator: aasmith
item.content:encoded:
University of the Arts London and London Studio Centre have agreed to end merger discussions, it is announced today.
London Studio Centre’s courses have been validated by the University since 2002 and the two institutions have since been exploring options to collaborate more closely, including a full merger. However, following recent discussions, both partners have concluded that their interests are best served by remaining separate.
University of the Arts London, which merged with Drama Centre London in 1999, remains ambitious to develop its performing arts provision and will seek alternative opportunities.
Nigel Carrington, Rector, University of the Arts London, said:
“It’s disappointing that a merger with LSC has not proved to be possible, but the parties were not able to reach agreement on financial and other contractual aspects of the proposed merger.
“The performing arts are an area in which the University is keen to develop further and studio space at our new King’s Cross campus has been designed for flexible performance teaching and practice. We are very excited about the opportunities this opens up for collaborations focusing on various aspects of performance.”
Nic Espinosa, Director, London Studio Centre, said:
“London Studio Centre has an outstanding reputation and contributes uniquely to dance provision in the higher education sector in the UK. Collaboration with the University of the Arts London has been beneficial but the time is now right to develop new partnerships to build on the excellent traditions of the Centre’s existing pedagogy. The decision to remain independent has been taken in the light of the government’s adoption of new funding structures for higher education and the Centre’s wish to maintain the integrity of its current provision.”
As part of the agreement, LSC’s degrees will cease to be validated by University of the Arts London from intake 2011. Students currently studying on a University of the Arts-validated course will continue to be supported throughout their course as normal by staff at LSC and will receive a University of the Arts London degree.

item.title: The Dandyism of Contempt
item.dc:creator: lauralanceley
item.content:encoded:
Photos by Leo Koivistoinen

Chelsea MA Fine Art students, alumni and staff, including course leader Brian Chalkley and artist Mark McGowan took to the stage at Camden Town Unlimited in ‘The Dandyism of Contempt’. This performance art event was curated by Vanessa Mitter and Joshua Y’Barbo who graduated from Chelsea Ma Fine last year and featured performances by Mark McGowan, Brian ‘Dawn’ Chalkley, Jack Catling, The Skinjobs, Nicola Ruben Montini, Robin Bale, Douglas Park,  Adham Faramawy,  Alec Dunnachie,  Pauline A. Amos, John Wild,  James Gardiner, Kiki Taira,  Lennie Lee,  Frog Morris,  Karl Weill and Edward Cotterill.

Photos provided by Leo Koivistoinen

Listed below are links to three of the performers’ works in the show.

Robin Bale’s spoken word/sound piece: http://podcast33638.podomatic.com/entry/2011-01-23T09_33_36-08_00

James Gardiner’s spoken word piece http://soundcloud.com/james-gardiner/untitled 
 
Nicola Ruben Montini’s performance http://vimeo.com/19173396

and here is a link to Nicola Ruben Montini’s footage of the show 
http://vimeo.com/19658645.

The show essay written by artist Robin Bale is below.

THE DANDYISM OF CONTEMPT
“Contrary to what a lot of thoughtless people seem to believe, dandyism is not even an excessive delight in clothes and material elegance. For the perfect dandy, these things are no more than the symbol of the aristocratic superiority of his mind” Charles Baudelaire “The Dandy”1

“We” are not “All In This Together.”

The original dandies dressed like you – that is to say, like anyone2. They took on “the Buff and the Brown”, the uniform of the American Revolutionaries – those slave-owning avatars of egalite. The difference was in the individuality of the cut; an impeccable silhouette might, perhaps, assuage the sting of merely being subsumed into that tedious, newly minted abstraction -“The People”.

In opposition to the blunt bluffness of the democratic Everyman, whose sober attire  was a sign of the bearer’s public virtue, they disguised themselves as themselves. They displayed – I was about to say “their otherness in public view”, but this not only lacks precision, but is also misleading. Their otherness as the public is closer to the mark, but might imply a collision between private inclination and civic demands. Apparently trivial details on the surface of appearance, the minute stitching of a button hole, a knot on a cravat or the width of a lapel, signalled the otherness of the public, its difference from, and incapability of being reduced to, itself.

This index of withdrawal, invisibility, was a style3 in the most serious sense of the word; and style, as the tangible arrangement of elements, is always serious.

Contempt, to be elegant – as wholeness or necessity – has to be marked with a totality – that is to say –like any totality – artificial, or symbolic. It has to be raised above its everyday self to become its own sign, stark against its shifting background. It requires a gesture that inscribes a circle that encloses itself. That which is mixed with, say, compassion or indulgence, belongs too much to the heterogeneous world.

Contempt is sterile. Closed within itself, it expresses only itself – ultimately its own difference from itself. In this world, there are only two qualities, the gesture and its background. To this gesture, all is background, and it indicates this with subtle and weary brevity. It neither genuflects, nor grieves.

Dandyism is a form of address, a subtle inclination forwards, merely enough to display a hint of shirt front and the cut of the sleeve. The immaculate contains itself, gives little more to the world than its scent.

The surface, the gesture that encloses itself, gives a brief farewell – perpetually departing.  A sign of legitimacy external to all other forms can do no other; it cannot explain itself. It barely acknowledges what it departs from; marks its own difference/indifference to it with the briefest nod – not even something that could be called a glance.

“Whether the Lumpen … present themselves as paupers, dandies, or poets makes little difference. They are, in any case, beings without dignity (if anything, they have majesty). What deprives them of dignity is precisely their contact with something extrasocial and self-sufficient, true nefas: pleasure, the invisible, the gratuitousness of art…as soon as he speaks of l’art pour l’art … his insolent retort, in a cracked falsetto, to the power that has stripped him of authority. Since he no longer has a function and has been banished from Court, he spurns every function”.
Roberto Calasso, “The Ruin of Kasch”

 “Nefas” here, is the deepest level of offence – adherence to something beyond getting, spending, voting: a subject whose legitimacy (in the sovereign sense) derives from something different to a deeply prosaic and disappointing participation in the role Homo Economicus. That apparently hard-wired “enlightened self-interest” has recently displayed remarkable results.

Zurbaran’s “St Francis in meditation”, which can be seen at the National Gallery, depicts a man (or Saint, if you prefer) wearing a monk’s habit, clutching a skull. He kneels in a starkly lit concavity. The painting is a study in holes. The shadow cast by his cowl dissolves most of his face, except where the strong chiaroscuro reveals the tip of his nose and, beneath that, his mouth, gaping in ecstasy or vacancy- a void within a void. The skull clutched in his praying hands is also illuminated; displaying its hollow sockets filled with the same darkness that has invaded Francis, who gulps at a vacuum. He is nothing more than a rough garment, torn at one elbow (the last detail, in stark illumination, is the stray threads on his torn robe) folded around a void. This space would, in fact, be invisible, if Zurbaran had not clothed it in hessian robes and painted light. This is Zurbaran’s version of St Francis of Assisi. He does not depict the devotee of brotherly love in the usual saccharine manner, not preaching to birds or beggars, but hollowed out, absent – as if the message of a radical equality can only come from, and maybe be addressed to, a place where the subject is no longer itself.

St Simeon Stylites stood at the top of a column for thirty six years. The column was periodically rebuilt, each time higher. Paradoxically, this incremental withdrawal from the common things of the earth, further into a solitary communion with his God, led to his ever greater visibility. His increasing elevation, index of his vanishing, must have been evident for miles around, like an ornament on its plinth.

“…there is no valid reason why we should not believe that the tribes we call savage are not the remnants of great civilizations of the past. Dandyism is a setting sun; like the declining star, it is magnificent, without heat and full of melancholy.”4

 1 http://www.dandyism.net/?page_id=178
2 “If people turn to look at you on the street, you are not well dressed.” Attributed to Beau Brummell
3 “…Every style embodies an epistemological decision, an interpretation of how and what we perceive…Every style is a means of insisting on something… It will be seen that stylistic decisions, by focusing our attention on some things, are also a narrowing of our attention, a refusal to allow us to see others.” Susan Sontag “On Style”

item.dc:creator: maya
item.content:encoded:
We’ve been chosen by The Edmond de Rothschild Foundations to participate as academic partner on the highly prestigious Ariane de Rothschild Prize.

The prize, first launched in Portugal in 2005, and then held in Brussels in 2008, is a travelling project. Its aim is to promote the work of unknown young artists (aged 22-35) from the country where that year’s prize is being held. The first prize is an artistic residency at a chosen art school (previously The Slade School of Art, UCL). The second and third prizes are monetary ones.

This year the prize will be held in Milano, during the MiArt fair, April 5-24 2011. Central Saint Martins will work with this year’s curators (Laura Barreca and Marcello Smarelli) and The Foundation, to determine the criteria for selecting the artists. We will also prepare the academic program for the winner.

item.title: Drama Centre alumnus Colin Firth nominated for Oscar
item.dc:creator: colin

Colin Firth and Vladimir Mirodan

Colin Firth has been nominated for an Oscar as best actor for his role in The King’s Speech. Earlier this month he won the Golden Globe award and he has been nominated for a BAFTA.

It is his second Oscar nomination following his first last year for ‘A Single Man’. Colin Firth was also nominated for a Golden Globe and he won the Best Actor BAFTA for the role. He has recently received the Hollywood Walk of Fame award.

Colin Firth came to Drama Centre London at Central Saint Martins in 2009 to speak to a packed hall of students about acting and his career. He answered many questions with great honesty and warmth and has recently strengthened his ties to the college by becoming Honorary President of The Friends of Drama Centre.

“It is very exciting to see one of our alumni build an impressive body of work that is recognised by the most prestigious awards,” says Principal of the Drama Centre, Professor Vladimir Mirodan, “Colin was always a very dedicated and gifted student and everyone here will be rooting for him on the night.”

Fellow alumnus, Tom Hardy, has been nominated for The Orange Wednesday Rising Star Award 2011.

item.title: A Call to Arms!
item.dc:creator: mtillett
item.content:encoded: Art group Charlesworth, Lewandowski & Mann are looking for collaborators to assist with the planning, production and build of a large-scale public artwork. As part of the Chelsea Programme project ‘If Not, Then What?’ (curated by Cecilia Wee), CL&M will be producing a temporary pavilion come battlement which will occupy the Rootstein Hopkins Parade Ground at Chelsea College of Art and Design from 1-13 March 2011. The structure will be the headquarters and centrepiece for a range of workshops, discussions, direct actions and other forms of resistance against the political and social upheaval that exists in Britain today. This would be an excellent opportunity to experience a live build from early planning stages to its final execution along with opportunities for creative input into the process. As well as enthusiasm and an interest in inputting into a live creative project, applicants should have a good working knowledge or willingness to learn basic structural woodwork and other construction techniques as well as a host of other manual and creative activities. The project will involve designing and fabricating structure for the RHPG and will involve working independently and in groups. The construction will be taking place over a 3 day period (1-3 March 2011). We would ideally like each helper to participate for 3 half days or more during the construction period, as well as attending a brief introduction session on Monday 21 February from 17.00 – 19.00. If you are interested in being involved, send a short statement of interest including information about your skills and experience to clandmeu@gmail.com by Friday 4 February. For more information about If Not, Then What? visit - http://cltad.arts.ac.uk/users/chelseaprogblog/ For more information about Charlesworth, Lewandowski & Mann visit - www.clandm.eu

item.title: Secrets of successful applications revealed at Portfolio Advice Day
item.dc:creator: aasmith
item.content:encoded: A strong portfolio is a crucial part of winning a place on a university art and design course, but what does it take to make your work stand out from the crowd?  Four hundred and fifty A level and BTEC students explored the answers to that question last month at University of the Arts London’s Portfolio Advice Day, which provided expert advice and guidance from course tutors, mock interviews with actors and informal chats about university life with current students. Held annually at Tate Britain, the day targets young people with no family background of higher education to give them the information and tools they need to win a place on an art and design degree course. More information about applying to university, including how to put together a winning portfolio, is at: http://www.portfolioadviceday.org.uk The next Portfolio Advice Day will take place in December 2011. Photographs by Catherine Wharfe, Tate Photography, copyright Tate Top tips for a winning portfolio DO label everything with your name, contact details and a short description DO include a contents list at the front of your portfolio DO show how each project developed from initial ideas to finished piece DO be consistent – use the same size and colour cards for mounting (white is usually best) DO make sure you can carry your portfolio for long periods of time DON’T roll up your work unless it’s really big DON’T use too heavy card – you have to carry it DON’T show a messy portfolio – it makes you look bad DON’T put too much in your portfolio DON’T use picture frames or coloured borders

Show continues February 16th – April 3rd 2011
Open seven days a week 11.00am – 6pm

Hepworth Court, Grosvenor Waterside, Gatliff Road (off Ebury Bridge Road), London SW1W 8QP

Chelsea Technician Richard Slatter will be presenting a body of recent work at Chelsea Futurespace Gallery after completing a three-month Foundry Fellowship, at Chelsea College of Art and Design.

The exhibition entitled ‘Deception-Depiction’ features recent bronze, aluminium and ceramic sculptures combined with preceding pieces.


Produced through ceramic slip casting and metal lost wax casting techniques, this method of working requires artistic exploration and experimentation within the casting process itself.  Language and narratives are presented, integrated and bound to each sculpture through its making.  Introspective qualities are evident and loom, whilst echoes of the range of materials used towards the formation of these sculptures, such as cardboard, fabric, bamboo, rope, buttons as well as wax, arouse intrigue.

‘Deception-Depiction’ will be accompanied by a colour publication containing a foreword by John Nicoll, the Foundry Manager at Chelsea College of Art & Design, and two written pieces by Susan Forsyth and Barbara Elting.

item.title: Christopher Kane wins BFC/Vogue Fashion Fund
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: This morning the British Fashion Council  named BFA 'New Designer of the Year 2007'  winner Christopher Kane as the recipient of this year’s BFC / Vogue Designer Fashion Fund. The CSM BA and MA Fashion graduate wins £200,000, plus access to mentors across the industry and a twelve-month bespoke mentoring programme from BFC. The Fund hopes to help Christopher's eponymous label make the transition from a developing creative business into a global fashion brand. Christopher's label is already stocked in stores around the world including Barneys, Jeffreys, Browns, Liberty, Dover Street Market, Harvey Nichols, Net-a-Porter, Joyce, Maria Luisa, Printemps and Corso Como. Christopher's talent was recognised early in his career, with stars such as Kylie commissioning stage outfits from the designer as early as 2007. Speaking on his latest commendation, he commented “I am absolutely delighted to be this year’s winner of the BFC /Vogue Designer Fashion Fund. It is such an honour to receive this accolade especially when I have such huge respect for all the nominees. The prize enables us to implement our strategic vision for the Christopher Kane business going forward. We would like to thank everyone involved in making this decision and all those who have helped establish our business. We would especially like to thank our team who work incredibly hard every day and without whom none of this would be possible.” University of the Arts London Alumni Association and BFC Chairman, Harold Tillman CBE, commented “The BFC/Vogue Designer Fashion Fund is focused on celebrating talents that have the potential to be successful British brands of the future.” Alexandra Shulman, Editor of British Vogue, said "I am delighted that Christopher Kane has won this year's award. His last collection was one of his best with a strong point of view but also clothes that all of us want to wear. He represents the best of British fashion talent - original, determined and influential.”

item.title: Letter to all staff from Heads of Colleges
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
31 January 2011
Dear colleagues
We are writing to advise you of the next phase of the College Efficiency Programmes, to explain the changes that are proposed and the reasons for them.
As you will know from extensive media coverage, the higher education sector is entering a period of radical change. The Government has already announced substantial cuts to university budgets, with institutions such as ours, which do not teach science, technology, engineering and maths, set to be hit particularly hard. We anticipate that the University’s HEFCE grant in 2011-12 will be reduced by between 7% and 10%, which means the total reduction in our expenditure needs to be at least £8 million.
The Government expects universities to make up the shortfall by increasing student tuition fees. Unfortunately, the first deep cuts to teaching funding will be implemented before universities can levy higher fees in 2012/13. That means we have no option but to make further savings now.
Central Services and Colleges have already made great steps to improve and streamline the way the University is run over the past two years, which has put us in a stronger position than many universities. However, we do still need to make significant staffing reductions, as well as savings in non-salary budgets and to increase income.
The next phase of efficiency measures is focused first on the University’s central administrative departments – specifically Academic Development and Services, Planning and Operations and the Rector’s Group, which incorporates Communications and Development, Finance and Human Resources. All four Colleges also need to reduce recurrent staffing costs, although there are fewer staff reductions at CSM during 2011/12 because CSM instigated reductions to staffing and consumables budgets in 2010/11 in the reorganisation of academic structures and its preparations for the move to King’s Cross. It has also accumulated one-off funds of its own for next year to help manage the transition to the new Kings Cross site.
All the Colleges have common aims in their efficiency programmes even though they have legitimately different mechanisms for achieving them. The first aim is the need to ensure that each College is able to reinvest its resources to deliver an excellent student experience. Second is the University’s academic mission to reduce its reliance on FE provision and increase postgraduate (and, where appropriate, research) capacity. Third is the need for ‘fit for purpose’ structures to support these academic aims.
The business case for each college, giving details of the proposed changes and the rationale, will shortly be available for staff to view on a password-protected area of the University website. We are aiming to notify all those whose posts are at risk of redundancy as a result of these changes by 4 February. The University is also undertaking an extensive review of Registry activities to explore how these may be delivered more effectively and efficiently, which may result in further savings across the University. We should know more about this from April onwards.
We are acutely aware that this is a deeply unsettling time, even for those who are not directly affected by the proposals, and we want to assure you that we are not taking these measures lightly. Colleges have so far managed to avoid compulsory redundancies in large numbers and we will continue to focus on redeploying staff where possible and offering advice and support where it is not possible.
Despite the difficult financial climate, we feel very optimistic about the University’s future as an internationally leading centre for arts, design and communication education and research. Our thanks go to all of you who have continued to work hard and maintain the quality of what we do despite the sometimes uncertain environment we have all been operating in.
We will continue to update you via the website and, when appropriate, by letter or email.
Yours sincerely
Frances Corner, Sandra Kemp, Jane Rapley, Chris Wainwright

item.title: LCF MA Collection of the Year announced
item.dc:creator: ssaggar
item.content:encoded:
Harold Tillman CBE announces Matteo Mollinari as LCF MA Collection of the Year

Last night London College of Fashion held its annual MA Fashion Design and Technology Show 2011 in the beautiful surroundings of the Raphael Gallery at the V&A. Stars and industry including,  Marina and the Diamonds, Jo Wood, Lulu Guinness, Grayson Perry, Harold Tillman, Jodie Harsh and Mel Blatt came out to support the 22 young graduate designers from Womenswear, Menswear and Digital Fashion.

The party continued after the show at the Polish Club in Kensington where guests were greeted with shots of Polish vodka.

As well as celebrity supporters, over 4500 viewers from all over the world logged onto the LCF website to watch the show – the first time the MA has been streamed live – following in the footsteps of major labels such as Giorgio Armani, Alexander McQueen and Louis Vuitton.

The big award of the night, Collection of the Year was presented by Harold Tillman CBE, Chairman of the British Fashion Council, owner of Jaeger and LCF alumnus. Out of a shortlist (compiled by an internal judging panel from LCF) of four including Queenie Huang, Mio Jin, Matteo Molinari and Jo Power, Collection of the Year was awarded to 27 year old, menswear designer, Matteo Molinari from Italy. His highly desirable and beautifully tailored collection fuses modern tailoring with traditional craftsmanship, with intricate hand-made crochet (see full biog below).

Over the past couple of years the MA graduate show has launched the careers of a huge number of exciting new designers including: Nicole Murray, Manjit Deu, Hasan Hejazi and Domingo Rodriguez.

To catch a glimpse of the collections you can also visit the LCF Graduate Exhibition at Victoria House which is open free to the public until 9 February.

To receive a daily email round-up of all coverage, subscribe to the Daily Press Bulletin by sending your email address to press.office@arts.ac.uk ** FT editor attacks 'dark arts' in press - The Financial Times Some national newspapers are operating a "conspiracy of silence" over phone hacking allegations at the News of the World, the editor of the Financial Times claimed at London College of Communication this week. At LCC's annual Cudlipp Lecture, Lionel Barber said UK journalists had "allowed our standards to lapse". He added: "Aside from the lead taken by the Guardian, which was followed by the FT, BBC and Independent, the rest of the newspaper industry took a pass on the News of the World phone-hacking story – almost certainly because they too were involved in ‘dark arts’." Young offenders exhibit their work at the National Gallery - The Guardian As paintings by men at Feltham Young Offenders Institution go on show at the National Gallery, the Guardian looks at the value of art education projects in prisons. One success story is John Costi, 23, now a student at Central Saint Martins. He says: If that had never happened, I doubt that I would be at Central Saint Martins today, and I doubt that I would be leading a law-abiding lifestyle. High-tech textiles - The Financial Times Reflective, dissolving, electric, purifying, movements-sensitive and, in some cases, even bullet-proof – the latest fashion fabrics could easily be the stuff of science fiction, says the Financial Times. While Japan has traditionally been known for fabric innovation, some of the most exciting developments originate in the UK. Designer Helen Storey, professor of fashion and science at the London College of Fashion, has helped create dissolving fabrics and air-purifying textiles. item.title: Sonya Dyer ‘Paul Robeson Research Station’
item.dc:creator: lauralanceley
item.content:encoded:
Sonya Dyer Paul Robeson Strasse Video still 2010 Courtesy the artist

Sonya Dyer , Chelsea Programme co-ordinator is currently exhibiting at the Site Gallery in Sheffield.  The exhibition ‘Paul Robeson Research Station’ was recommended as one to see in this weeks Guardian Guide and will run from 2-19 February 2011.
http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/gallery/2011/feb/05/exhibitionist-art-shows#/?picture=371389952&index=7

Paul Robeson Research Station presents a series of screenings, discussions and live mapping, culminating in a choral performance. Paul Robeson (1898 – 1976) was an American actor, singer, scholar, athlete, writer, lawyer, trade unionist and social justice advocate. The son of an escaped slave, he was at the forefront of the civil rights movement. Despite being a beloved international figure during his lifetime, he was persecuted and virtually erased from ‘mainstream’ US culture. Through discursive platforms, tomato growing and using the idea of the ‘anthem’ as a transnational symbol, the project aims to explore the legacy of Robeson as a symbol of workers solidarity, social justice and internationalism. Read more about the exhibition on the gallery website http://www.sitegallery.org/archives/3085

Sonya Dyer ‘s work uses a variety of means and contexts to investigate artists and political agency, rethinking historical and contemporary ideas of Europe and European culture.

Linked Events:

Film screenings
Two films starring Paul Robeson, each followed by a discussion with an invited speaker.

The Proud Valley (1940) – Wednesday 2 February, 6pm, With speaker Professor Lynda Morris

Song of Freedom (1936) – Wednesday 9 February, 6pm, With speaker Beverley Humphries (Paul Robeson Wales Trust)

Artist’s talk & discussion - Friday 18 February, 5pm - Chaired by Becky Shaw. Followed by choral event featuring the Sheffield Socialist Choir and refreshments.

Places to all events are free but space is limited so please book your place in advance by contacting events@sitegallery.org or reception on 0114 281 2077.

item.dc:creator: rjillions
item.content:encoded: EPSRC Creative Industries Knowledge Transfer Network Studentship - London College of FashionOne EPSRC doctoral award is now recruiting and will be available from May 2011. To be eligible for a full award (stipend and fees), applicants must have: Settled status in the UK, meaning they have no restrictions on how long they can stay Been 'ordinarily resident' in the UK for 3 years prior to the start of the grant. This means they must have been normally residing in the UK (apart from temporary or occasional absences) Not been residing in the UK wholly or mainly for the purpose of full-time education. (This does not apply to UK or EU nationals) To be eligible for a fees only award: All EU nationals are eligible to receive fees only if they do not have settled status in the UK Please also consult the EPSRC website containing information on the Industrial Case studentships for further information. If you are unsure of your residential eligibility, please consult the University of the Arts London's Fee Status Guidance Document which is used to assess student status as Home, EU or Overseas. Health monitoring through clothing A 3.5 year full-time studentship funded under the Industrial CASE award scheme, funded by EPSRC through the Creative Industries Knowledge Transfer Network. The studentship will pay your fees and provide a stipend of £13,570 (in Year 1, increasing in years 2-4). The studentship will be based at London College of Fashion, under the supervision of Professor Sandy Black. This design-led inter-disciplinary practical project will investigate novel applications for sensor-enabled knitted garments for the healthcare sector, and will be conducted in collaboration with industrial partner Smartlife. The successful candidate will have experience in one (or more) of the following areas: design for industrial knitting, product design, clothing/sportswear design and production, or technical textile technology. Applicants applying for the award should complete the standard application form on our University of the Arts London Research Degree MPhil/PhD application page  and indicate that they wish to be considered for an AHRC Doctoral Awards. The deadline for the applications to reach RMA Students Section is 2nd March 2011. The application should be typewritten/word processed and submitted electronically to: researchdegrees@arts.ac.uk If you need any further information on the application procedure please email Research Managements and Administration Students section - researchdegrees@arts.ac.uk or telephone 0207 514 9389 or 0207514 8437

item.title: On a journey No Found to New Documents
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: Social media is playing a role in revolutions around the world, from the political to the economic,  down to the romantic, retail and social. Less explicit is social media's effect on art and practitioners, with its potential for cross-border inspiration, collaboration and exchange. No Found to New Documents at Viktor Wynd Fine Art exhibits the work of  35 international artists, sourced by curator Emeric Glayse entirely through online searches, including the work of LCC alumna Rasha Kahil. The show operates as an experiment in simultaneous online shows and travelling physical exhibitions. Dazed Digital asked the curator why he chose to reference New Documents in the title of his show: "With works of Diane Arbus, Lee Friedlander and Garry Winogrand, New Documents 1967 was the first show in a Museum (MoMA) fully dedicated to snapshot photography. Because I work mainly with diary photographers and because, for me, Nofound to New Documents will bring Nofound into art spaces, I thought a wink at John Szarkowski's exhibition would be nice." Read more No Found to New Documents will be at Viktor Wynd Fine Art, 11 Mare street, E8 E8 4RP, until 28 February and online at www.nofoundtonewdocuments.com

item.title: Interview: Professor Louise Wilson OBE
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded:
Professor Louise Wilson is among the world's most influential fashion educators. Since 1992 Wilson has been the Director of the MA Fashion course at Central Saint Martins, one of the world's most influential and revered fashion courses. Wilson herself attended the course, graduating with an MA with distinction.  An exceptional ratio of her former students have gone on to influence the industry, usually after taking part in the annual graduation fashion show held during London Fashion Week each February. In her role as Course Director she has developed professional collaborations with, amongst others, Armani, Chloe, Dunhill, Lancome, L'Oreal, Puma, Bally and Pringle. Wilson was appointed full-time Design Director of Donna Karan women's collection New York in 1997 (taking a one year sabbatical from CSM) and continued in the role as a consultant until 2001. In 1999 she was awarded a Professorship at  University of the Arts London (then the London Institute). She was appointed an OBE for her services to education and the fashion industry in the 2008 Queen's Birthday Honours List. She continues to consult with leading companies worldwide.

What are you working on at the moment? Central Saint Martins Fashion Show during London Fashion Week. Pringle Archive Project design project with selected MA Fashion students. Bally men's footwear project both of which will also be exhibited during London Fashion Week at separate prestigious events.

What are your top tips for discovering new talent? NONE. Who is your one to watch? If I ever thought like that I should retire!! It is not the remit of my job. Who or what first inspired you to follow your chosen career? It was accidental. What are you most passionate about? Lack of skills!! Which drives me mad!! When people have first class degrees but no skills!! Which piece of art/design/performance/communication/fashion do you wish you had created? No point wishing best to get doing!! Where is your favourite London haunt? John Lewis, Oxford Street.

What is your guilty pleasure? I don't do pleasure. Name a favourite book, song or film I don't do favourites. What is your signature dish? Custard.

What’s next for you? Africa.

item.title: Lady Gaga wears MA graduate designs
item.dc:creator: mlanglands
item.content:encoded:
Last night, Lady Gaga, the multi talented singer-songwriter and exhibitionist with a flair for theatrics, arrived for her appearance on ‘The Tonight Show with Jay Leno’ in Los Angeles wearing a creation by 2011 London College of Fashion MA graduate Dinu Bodiciu.

Lady Gaga wearing designs by Dinu Bodiciu. Image Credit: EROTEME.CO.UK

Dinu, who only showed his final collection at the MA Catwalk show at London’s V&A Museum two weeks ago, had his designs spotted on the catwalk and called in by Lady Gaga’s team of stylists, known collectively as ‘The Haus of Gaga’.

Dinu, from Timisoara in Romania, enrolled onto the MA Fashion Design Technology: Womenswear course at LCF after his background in Graphic Design enriched his desire to further his design skills. His final collection draws on the dichotomy between illusion and reality. In his collection, Dinu has brought the two worlds together – on first glance the outfits appear flat – as they would in a mirror – but in reality the garments are structured, 3 dimensional pieces with bold shoulders and strong silhouettes. The colour palette represents the heat from the body – from greys and nudes through to red.

Dinu Bodiciu's collection on the catwalk. Image Credit: Catwalking.com

item.title: Going crazy for Gaga
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: Gaga-mania has reached new peaks, with  LCF student Anna Chong's minature  of the controversial pop princess, replete with incy costumes, becoming the latest must-have accessory. Grazia reports "the collection comprises nine of La Gaga’s best-known outfits, including the iconic rubber dress ... BUT, most brilliantly loon-based of all, is a pint sized version of Gaga’s now-infamous meat dress. .. the meat dress took Anna ‘two weeks to create as she tested numerous outfits made from salami, honey roasted ham and raw beef strips before settling on a number made using the finest quality Parma ham.’  The result, however, is a pretty impressive - if ever-so-slightly pallid - recreation of the dress Lady G wore to last year’s VMA’s." Read more on Grazia and the Telegraph . See how to create your own mini meat masterpiece on YouTube. As famous for her fierce fashion sense as her world-dominating chart hits, this week the planet's most famous exhibitionist kept at the cutting-edge of style  sporting the debut collection from  Dinu Bodici. Dinu appeared on the scene just two weeks ago, fresh from his LCF MA Fashion course. The "new Madonna" set the paparazzi bulbs popping when she arrived in LA for her appearance on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno in the hot young designer's blistering red trouser suit. Dinu reveals "My work focuses on explorations of human body and its interaction with garments. I perceive garment as an extension of the body and I am interested in its ‘organic’ nature. The collection takes as a starting point the concept of mirror stage in psychoanalysis broadly defined as the moment when we became conscious of our identity by discovering our reflection in the mirror." item.title: Smells Like Teen Spirit
item.dc:creator: acastleton
item.content:encoded: Ground-breaking researcher Jenny Tillotson will be making her debut on the cult TEDx YouTube channel later this week, when footage from  TEDxGranta: Women Shaping the Future hits the airwaves. A Senior Research Fellow in the sensory, aroma and medical field in Fashion and Textiles Design  at Central Saint Martins, a Fellow of the Royal Society of the Arts and a STEM Science and Engineering Ambassador, Jenny took part in the TED cast on on 15 February as part of  TEDx Granta, a fast-paced,  curated program featuring TED’s famous 18-minute talks, to pose thought-provoking ideas and in particular to highlight how women have shaped the world and are continuing to shape the future. A visionary in the field of Scentsory Design ® , which explores the relationship between aromas and emotional wellbeing, Jenny is currently working with the Institute of Biotechnology at the University of Cambridge to connect fashion with material science, developing simpler, better consumer ‘wellness’ products which use the sense of smell as a communication tool. Her practice seeks to "invent clothes with computerised scent-output systems worn on the body for health, wellbeing and drug delivery applications." Scentient Beings, Jenny's research project,  explores the concept of Re-cabling Fashion, by implanting smell technology into multi-sensorial clothing on a more active approach to fashion design, introducing the living dress as a sensitive Smart Second Skin. This would have applications including combating mood disorders and improving the wearer's emotional state. Ultimately, Jenny dreams of  "miniaturising the technology she has created for the e.scent project [to] embed this is a new WONDER book", which she plans to write with her children.  "Above all, my deep desire is to change the life of women". Read more about Jenny's ground-breaking research. See Jenny's TED cast on YouTube.

item.title: ‘Fanzines’ reviewed in ‘The New York Times’
item.dc:creator: lcc head of college blog news
item.content:encoded:
Fanzines (front cover) by Teal Triggs

Teal Triggs’ latest book, Fanzines, has received critical acclaim in The New York Times Sunday Book Review.

In his weekly column, Steven Heller, the highly respected design writer and former art director for The New York Times, describes the book as:

“… an exceptional resource for anyone looking to get an eyeful of these ‘oppositional or subcultural’ publications in all their carelessly shoddy glory”.

Published by Thames & Hudson and launched at LCC last September, the book is a comprehensive guide to everything zines. Arranged chronologically in six chapters, each with a thorough introduction, Fanzines spans eight decades of counterculture and features many extremely rare publications.

Triggs, Professor of graphic design and course director of MA Design Writing Criticism at LCC, has written extensively for the international design press and co-authored several books on design including the Typographic Experiment and Communicating Design: Essays in Visual Communication.

Below are three UK zines featured in the book.

'Ripped & Torn' (1976-1979) produced by Tony Drayton covering the Punk scene in London and Glasgow

Arty (2001) a London-based art zine produced by Cathy Lomax

'Feverzine' is produced by Alex Zamora and designed by Simon Whybray

And if that wasn’t enough to whet your appetite, the LCC Library Zine Collection is due to go on show at the ICA’s Fox Reading Room. Check our News & Events blog for more info.

item.title: Relocating our print workshops to the Byam Shaw campus at Archway
item.dc:creator: colin
item.content:encoded:
We realise that some of our students are concerned about the relocation of the print workshops from Southampton Row to the Byam Shaw campus at Archway when we move to King’s Cross. We would like to clarify the situation to avoid any misunderstanding.

If you have any concerns after reading the points below, please ask a question in the comments. Alternatively you can write/talk to your Dean or to Jim Thrower, the new Technical Coordinator for the 2D area, who is in charge of planning the technical resources for print. His email is j.thrower@csm.arts.ac.uk.

  1. There won’t be any reduction in the number of presses available to students – in fact there will be more! This is because the presses being moved to Archway will be supplemented by those already there, which aren’t currently available to Southampton Row Graphic Design students. This will make your practice more, rather than less hands-on.
  2. The additional facilities at Archway will include:
    1. Litho works
    2. Silkscreen facilities
    3. The hydraulic press currently situated at Back Hill, which is also being moved to Archway.
  3. All the technicians, except one, currently at Southampton Row will be there to support you at Archway.
  4. Archway is 20 minutes from King’s Cross on the bus. The Byam Shaw campus at Archway is an integral part of Central Saint Martins – the two campuses at King’s Cross and Archway are fully integrated and planned together. We’ll be making sure that you don’t have to move between the two sites unnecessarily.
  5. We’ve relocated the presses to Archway because we wanted to give you more space and more access, not less. This will also help to meet student demand for digital printing at King’s Cross. This decision is all about responding to student needs – it’s not about changing our focus to digital.

Last week we posted about the launch of the South London Art Map and Last Fridays happening this Friday 25 February. We just got given a sneak preview of the limited edition badge available on the night and wanted to share it with you!

South London-based artist and Camberwell BA Painting tutor Hew Locke has been commissioned by Tate Modern to create a limited edition badge for the launch of the South London Art Map. The enamelled badges take the form of a parakeet motif, an image chosen by the artist to represent South London. The South London Art Map initiative includes a printed map and interactive website featuring over 90 art galleries, co-ordinated Last Fridays late gallery openings and art tours of South London.

The free badges will be available exclusively for the launch. The badges can be picked up from any of the participating venues on a first come first served basis from 18.30 onwards until stocks last. Intended to be worn while visiting the venues on the South London Art Map route during the evening, the badge connects South London art venues in a united invitation to explore the art scene of South London.

Hew Locke said ‘the inspiration came from the small flock of green ring-necked parakeets that appeared in my local Brockwell Park a few years ago. The next thing I hear, these exotics are taking over South London, and what was once charming and pretty is now under threat of culling. In my mirrored design of birds on the badge, their tails start to look like a skull – a reference to the home of the main South London flock in Norwood Cemetery.’

Both Camberwell Space and Peckham Space are participating.

Image: Limited edition badge by Hew Locke commissioned by Tate Modern for the South London Art Map launch.

item.title: Beatrice Boyle Exhibition at London College of Fashion
item.dc:creator: mlanglands
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_21359" align="alignnone" width="540" caption="Guests at the Beatrice Boyle Exhibition opening night. Image credit: Sam Todd"][/caption] Last Thursday 17 March, to coincide with the beginning of London Fashion Week, London College of Fashion opened the doors to its new exhibition by Beatrice Boyle – rising fashion star and LCF graduate. This exciting new exhibition, which brings her back to London College of Fashion, comprises of large scale works which merge painting and photography. Exploring further the method of deconstruction, Beatrice has used techniques to deface the photographs and subvert the original image with instinctive, destructive brushstrokes. First to see her beautiful new work at the exclusive preview were guests such as, Simon Burstein from trailblazing boutique BROWNS who gave Beatrice her first big break after plucking her straight from her graduate show and designers, journalists and industry supporters; and those party hopping on the first night of the fashion week calendar. Beatrice’s first collection with Browns Focus was a huge success and coverage followed in Harper’s Bazaar, Grazia, Sunday Times Style, Plastique, Dazed & Confused, Elle and Vogue.com. Her distinctive and iconic designs were spotted on stars including Cheryl Cole. [caption id="attachment_21364" align="alignnone" width="364" caption="Beatrice Boyle next to her work. Image credit: Sam Todd"][/caption] Depicting anonymous subjects, Beatrice’s paintings have one dominant motif; women. The women are a distressed, dishevelled version of their former self, there is a tension between the original image and this portrayal. The brushstrokes distort and violate the image and transform it into something transgressive and sinister.
Speaking of her new work Beatrice commented: “When I paint I am transforming the original image and to a certain extent, destroying it. In that destruction there is the creation of something new. The process of painting subverts the image. It is the juxtaposition of the glamorous and the sordid that has inspired me and taken my work in a new direction.”
Having studied BA Fine Art at Central Saint Martins prior to her degree at London College of Fashion in BA (Hons) Fashion Illustration, Beatrice has immersed herself in both the worlds of fine Art and Fashion. Her signature style has developed from working with images ripped from glossy fashion magazines and advertising campaigns, images of flawless models which she then destroys using paint and brush stokes to deftly create an aesthetic and subtext entirely different from the original depiction of glamour. [caption id="attachment_21377" align="alignnone" width="388" caption="Work on display at the Beatrice Boyle Exhibition. Image Credit: Sam Todd"][/caption] In recent work Beatrice has used her own photography as the starting point for her paintings, selecting the model and constructing the image entirely, adding another layer to the process in which she works. The exhibition is located on the RHS Terrace and is free and open to the public from Friday 18 February to Thursday 3 March from 10.00 am – 5.00 pm daily (closed Sunday).
