item.title: CCW Artist Moving Image Initiative Awardees Announced
item.dc:creator: llanceley
item.content:encoded:
A site by, for and about Artist Moving Image at Chelsea, Camberwell and Wimbledon Colleges of Art. http://ccwartistmovingimage.wordpress.com/2011/02/21/ccw-artist-moving-image-initative-awardees-announced/ Below are the 10 Awardees who will receive funds to complete the following projects that will premier at South London Gallery on May 11th 2011. [caption id="attachment_21360" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project Name: Amy Curtis at 21"][/caption] Lydia O’Hara (Director) Ba Fine Art at Chelsea College of Art and Design, Grey Chen (Cinematographer) Ba Graphic Design at Camberwell College of Arts. The project we are working on involves working with Amy Curtis, a 71 year old lady from Brixton. We will be recreating some memories of hers, which involved her going dancing – she loved to dance and went as often as she could. I will be playing the role of Amy, as I’m 21 years old now and that is the sort of time frame we are looking to relive for her, and she will be helping to direct the film to be as close to how she remembered it as possible. www.lydiaohara.com
[caption id="attachment_21365" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project name: TRANSMISSION"][/caption]
Eleanor Fusaro & Sophie Hanson (Chelsea School of Art and Design, BA Fine Art Year 3) TRANSMISSION is a short abstract film following the conventions of a series in three parts. Taking visual cues from David Lynch and Michael Haneke, the piece explores the concept of the marriage of human and machine. Adopting a non linear format, the ambiguous constructs create a sense of disorientation and unease. [caption id="attachment_21366" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project name: Isle of the Dead/Revisited"][/caption] Michael Slusakowicz – director Sarah Doerfel – actress The film is inspired by Arnold Böcklin‘s ‘Isle of the Dead’ and uses the painting as a starting point of the story. The intention was to focus on characteristics of Symbolism embodied in paintings. The aim of the film was to introduce Symbolism to unfamiliar with the History of Art viewers. http://familiarend.blogspot.com/ [caption id="attachment_21367" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project Name: Primitive Screen"][/caption] Jack Friswell, PTBM 3, Wimbledon College of Art Joseph Curran, PTBM 2, Wimbledon College of Art Christel Woodford, Costume Design 3, Wimbledon College of Art ‘Primitive Screen’ is a single screen moving image work developed in collaboration between Jack Friswell and Joseph Curran. The foundation of the film beholds a 16mm projector and screen situated in an archetypal primordial settlement in which inhabitants will watch a separate film play out. Essentially we will be making two films, one to be projected within the other. The materiality of film and the projection of light, as ritualistic and cathartic, is key to the work. [caption id="attachment_21368" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project Name: virtual exhibition tour"][/caption]Josie Cockram, Tomas Kemp, Mike Doorly, Lucas Dillon, Karen Blake (3rd year BA Sculpture and Drawing students at Camberwell College of Arts) Aaron Harris, Trevor Porter (2nd year BA Sculpture students at Camberwell College of Arts) Jack Greeley-Ward (2nd year sound student at London College Communication) Production Assistance: Grey Chen (Camberwell College of Arts 2nd year BA student): camera Andrew Ford (a 2nd student at LCC): sound engineer Our intention is to make a film based on ideas about virtual exhibition tours. We will be staging an exhibition in a disused chapel and, taking this show as a point of departure, the film will re-imagine and re-curate the initial experience. Approaching the work of eight students, working with both digital media and material sculpture, the film will question translations between objects, the spaces they occupy and their later appearance in digital imagery. Colleges involved: Camberwell, LCC [caption id="attachment_21369" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Mei Homma, Chelsea College of Art and Design, MA Fine Art"][/caption] This project is video based and about my experiences on London buses. When I have been on the buses in London, I have realised I can hear many kinds of languages, even though I am in London. I would like to film scenes of London and have English subtitles appear for the many languages which I will come across in my videos. [caption id="attachment_21372" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project Name: Diaspora"][/caption] The film hopes to broaden dialogue about diaspora in london and challenge the notion of returning back to your homeland to ‘discover’ your roots. It also hopes to explore the idea of a ‘home away from home’- the diaspora phenomena of little communities and clusters of certain diasporic nations inhabitating and transforming areas of London into their ‘home’ nations. Names of group members: William Phong-Ly Sarah Adetola Dilara Kaplanbosoglu George Thermistoculous Tom Kikuchi Charles Chung Colleges involved: Chelsea College of Art and Design Lambeth Sixth Form College London College of Music University of Greenwich [caption id="attachment_21373" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Project Name: Lost Architecture in Peckham"][/caption] Project Title: Lost Architecture in Peckham by Mary Vettise, Camberwell College of Arts and Design Lost Architecture in Peckham is a 15 minute long ‘documentary’ shot in black-and-white super 8 film. The subject of this film is recent urban redevelopment in Peckham, South-east London. Over the course of the film the ‘artist’ narrates her futile search for buildings that now only exist in memory and in photography. [caption id="attachment_21374" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Anna Moderato"][/caption] Colleges: Chelsea College of Art and Design When we look at an object we form an immediate impression, based on experience, of what it would feel like to touch, how heavy it is, the sound it would make if dropped etc. We also form an idea of how it would move, what possibilities that particular object has. When tested these intuitive impressions are often proven wrong; reality can be a much stranger place than our common-sense allows it to be. [caption id="attachment_21376" align="aligncenter" width="470" caption="Machina"][/caption] Machina explores the nature of consumerism and technology. The junkyard becomes a playground for thoughts on material concerns. From Chelsea College of Art and Design Rajee Shyama Ed simpson Joe Mania

item.title: London Street Photography Festival – call for submissions
item.dc:creator: colin
item.content:encoded:
The new London Street Photography Festival is calling for submissions!

Candid, un-staged photography which captures, explores or questions contemporary society and the relationships between individuals and their surroundings.  Street photography is more a method than a genre. The results can fit into documentary, portraiture and other genres, but the key elements of spontaneity, careful observation and an open mind ready to capture whatever appears in the viewfinder are essential.

Submission deadline: 31 March
Festival: 7-17 July

Prizes include: an Olympus PEN camera worth £500 for the winner; tuition and a show at Orange Dot Gallery for 6 finalists; a voucher toward publishing your own book with Blurb for all entrants.

item.title: Imagining Commoniveristy Workshop
item.dc:creator: mtillett
item.content:encoded: Monday 28 - Wednesday 30 March 2011 As part of Chelsea Programme’s ongoing series of projects critiquing the current climate of austerity and creating space for exciting visions of the future, we are delighted to announce the forthcoming workshop, Imagining Commoniversity. Led by Spanish collective Hackitectura.net, (represented by Pablo de Soto and Alejandro González) and coordinated by Emanuele Guidi and Lorenzo Sandoval, Imagining Commoniveristy will take place within the context of the ongoing project Visualizing Transnationalism. Hackitectura.net and project participants  will work together to imagine what a common University in Europe could look like, how it could work and what its role in society could be. Through mapping strategies, open collective discussions and the implementation of new media technologies, Hackitectura.net will build on the experience and tradition of British groups such as Archigram, to sketch and design the ‘vision’ of a utopian Common University of the future. There are 20 places available for this workshop, including 7 spaces for UAL students / staff. The workshop will take place at Chelsea College of Art and Design. For more detailed information, including information on how to apply, please visit - http://cltad.arts.ac.uk/users/chelseaprogblog/ Deadline: Sunday 20 March 2011. Successful applicants will be notified by Tuesday 22 March 2011. Part of Transeuropa Festival 2011 Watch: Student Protest>Hackitectura Lab >Mapping the Commons Supported by the European Cultural Fund, European Alternatives and Chelsea Progamme.

item.title: Seeing Voices: Inside BT Archives
item.dc:creator: aasmith
item.content:encoded: The development of the phone from functional tool to object of desire is explored next month in a series of mini-installations inspired by artefacts, images and sounds from BT Archives. Seeing Voices: Inside BT Archives brings to life themes including how advertising positioned the phone as a must-have lifestyle accessory and how the language of telephony was invented. Designed by MA Design Writing Criticism students at London College of Communication, the interactive installations allow visitors to recreate the sex and glamour of 1970s and 80s advertising, hear audio of early telephonists and the first long distance calls, and discover how the “magic” behind the phone was explained to its first users. The students have published their responses to the archive in Fieldstudy, a collection of seven studies that interpret artefacts and ideas from the archive within the history of telecommunications. The seven studies that have inspired the installations are: *In Phone, In Fashion, an examination of advertisements of the 70s and 80s which use images of “glossy women” to position the phone as a desirable purchase, marking the emergence of phone shops which allowed customers to buy their own phone rather than rent from BT. *A Very British [Design] Coup, showing how the GPO used graphic designers for the first time to create iconic advertisements *Scripting The Future Of Technology, looking at how the language of telephony was formalised, including very precise instructions to telephonists on how to pronounce numbers *Still Closer Together, exploring how long distance calling changed our perception of distance and even brought Queen Elizabeth II closer to her dominions * Shorthand Science And Magic Lessons, a study of how early users were introduced to the technology of telephony through the language of enchantment *With Kindest Regards, the tale of an exhibition that never was through the voices of eleven GPO public relations officers who tried, and failed, to create a travelling telephone exhibition for the Graham Bell centenary *Modern Call, an investigation of the role of artists in communicating the complexities and excitement of new technology to the public Seeing Voices: Inside BT Archives 2 March – 11 March 2011 Well Gallery, London College of Communication, London SE1 6SB Monday – Friday 10am-6pm, Saturday 10am-4pm.
